newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: OLYMPICS-SYDNEY BED TAX ROW PUT TO REST.
newsitem.headline: OLYMPICS-SYDNEY BED TAX ROW PUT TO REST.

text.p: A row between Sydney hotels and the New South Wales state government over a planned city bed tax was put to rest on Tuesday, allowing organisers of the 2000 Olympic Games to get back to signing up major sponsors.

Games chiefs were forced to put A$600 million (US$440 million) worth of sponsorship deals on hold last month after hoteliers protesting against the new 10 percent accommodation levy refused to guarantee them rooms.
Under a compromise deal announced on Tuesday, Sydney city hotels promised to make 80 percent of their beds available for Olympic needs in return for a phasing-in of the tax.

"This agreement overcomes a significant problem which had arisen in our preparations for the Games. We can now proceed with confidence," Sydney Organising Committee for the Olympic Games (SOCOG) president Michael Knight said.
Despite the deal, the bed tax headache will not immediately disappear for either the NSW government or SOCOG.

SOCOG vice-president John Coates, a lawyer who heads the Australian Olympic Committee, last week launched a defamation action against NSW state treasurer Michael Egan for having suggested that Coates's opposition to the tax might be motivated by his business links with a company which runs a city hotel.

Under the compromise, SOCOG itself sacrificed some A$6 million it had been due to charge as commission for providing clients with hotels. The organising body agreed to cut its own commission on rooms from 10 to five percent.
In return it is able to go ahead with major sponsorship deals which the row had threatened.
SOCOG officials had said they would have to renegoiate the deals at much lower rates because sponsors could not be guaranteed a room if there were no cooperation from the hotels.

"Although we've had a few difficult months, SOCOG is now in a better position to sign up accommodation than we were at the beginning of the dispute over bed tax between the government and the industry," Knight, who is also the NSW Olympics minister, said in a statement.

The SOCOG concession on its own commission was one element in a compromise deal between the hotel industry and the New South Wales government, which is underwriting the cost of staging the Games. Hoteliers said the deal would save them a total of A$40 million.
In announcing changes to the bed tax legislation, state premier Bob Carr said the hotel levy would be reduced from 10 percent to five percent at the start of the phasing-in period in September, 1997.
But he said the reduction would apply only for hotels which sign agreements with SOCOG before the end of the year.
Cruise ships berthing in Sydney during the Olympics will be exempt. In addition, serviced apartments will be exempt from the bed tax for stays of 28 days or longer.
